title: Preserve case behaves unexpectedly, taking caps from both source and replace
body:
#78133

For this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/62153009-88c74c80-b2b8-11e9-8096-e097da9daca0.png)

The case of only the first capital from the search result is retained, not the second

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/62153022-8fee5a80-b2b8-11e9-9167-4046a4919660.png)

---

For this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/62153120-c4faad00-b2b8-11e9-9fb1-88e72064a8c0.png)

The case of the first capital from the search result is retained, not the second. The cap in the replace term is retained, but not the lowercase first letter

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2193314/62153160-d348c900-b2b8-11e9-8ae2-0e9008f68844.png)

---

Maybe this isn't supported yet as per https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/78133, it would be very confusing to people trying to use an incomplete feature though.

title: Reuse launchBrowser window tab

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
It is really nice that we can F5 debug and launch our web applications. A nice improvement would be to reuse the window if you debug more than once. Currently, a new duplicate tab will be created every time you launch.

The only current solution that I know of is a little silly and involves having two almost duplicate launch tasks, one to open the window and one to skip doing that. I still have to remember to refresh the tab when the building is complete.

Other tools like react will reuse the same tab and refresh the content. This is a really nice developer feature and a productivity boost.

Can we add this functionality?

moved from https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/issues/3152

title: VSCode freezes/crashes Windows 10 1809
body:
Hi, we are experiencing weird behaviour with VSCode and Win10 at the office.
My co-worker and I both have the same machines with Windows 10 1809 installed and noticed that VSCode will eventually soft freeze the whole operating system.

Once the system is frozen (by reproducing using the steps), all windows except for Google chrome and chromium based applications (Google Chrome, Slack, VSCode) are visually responsive, but nothing else happens when interacting with the operating system or UI elements - just as if someone pulled the plug from the SSD/HDD. For example: Launching a shell and trying to ping results in the cmd window freezing.

We will have to hard reboot our machines TWICE - rebooting once does not work, as Windows 10 will stay on the grey loading screen (with the spinner) forever - or even randomly lock out the drive and ask for a bitlocker recovery key (but not after the second (!) reboot).

This issue may be related to #49425 , but should be fixed by now with Windows 10 1809 ?!
WIN+CTRL+SHIFT+B doesn't help here :)

- VSCode Version: 1.36.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 1809

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Google Chrome
2. Open VSCode
3. Either close VSCode or open multiple instances (workspaces) and switch between them.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

{

      "name": "Launch Program",
      "program": "${workspaceFolder}/hello.js",
    }
  ]
}
```

title: Open existing keybindings in new editor
body:
Closes #77696

When setting a keybinding, the desired key combination can already exist. A button is
provided to go to that list. Before this PR, clicking on the button would trigger a search on the
current _Keyboard Shortcuts_ tab, therefore removing the command for which you were trying to
set a shortcut.
This PR modifies that functionnality, and opens a new _Keyboard Shortcuts_ tab, in different editor
group.

title: Running/configuring tasks hangs when gulpfile has a top level watch()
body:
Issue Type: Bug ### Steps to reproduce: * Create a new directory and have it open in vscode * Have gulp available either globally or locally (`npm install --save-dev gulp`) * Create a gulpfile.js with the following contents: ``` const { watch } = require('gulp'); watch("*.*", () => {}); ``` * Close and re-open vscode * Try executing any of the task-related commands, for example: **Configure Default Build Task** / **Run Build Task** / **Run Task** ### Result The commands hang on "Fetching build tasks..." ### Culprit The built-in Gulp support extension. Disabling it fixes the issue. title: Few new commands for find/replace
body: Issue Type: Feature Request Commands like editor.action.addSelectionToNextFind/editor.action.replaceOne add cursors or show a find/replace panel. I need simpler commands which do not do those things. I would like to find or replace simply. I would like use these commands: 1. editor.action.addSelectionToFindVariable, 2. editor.action.addSelectionToReplaceVariable, 3. editor.action.FindVariable, 4. editor.action.replaceOneWithVariable 5. editor.action.replaceAllWithVariable The first one should copy a selected text in the editor to a find variable. The second one should copy a selected text in the editor to a replace variable. The third one should select each occurrence of a text equaled the find variable in the editor gradually. The fourth one should replace the selected text with the replace variable. The fifth one should replace all occurrences of a text equaled the find variable with the replace variable. I will assign keyboard shortcuts to the commands. VS Code version: Code 1.36.1 (2213894ea0415ee8c85c5eea0d0ff81ecc191529, 2019-07-08T22:59:35.033Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17134

title: Clear Simple Mac Shortcuts
body:
Can you provide proper information about shortcuts for Mac please.  It is annoying to see this desinforming shortcuts showing on Mac machines for VS Code.

For example, F5 - start debugging is what menu shows in VSC but F5 actually starts Voice Over, not debugging.  I know Mac does not respect F keys but then make simple one-hand shortcuts and show them in VSCode for Mac.

I also know I can override Mac to follow F keys but that disables Mac functionality, i.e Volume Up or Volume Down needs to be used with Fn+F11/Fn+F12 which what most people dont want to fudge with.

Considering the maturity and popularity of VSC, I'd say it is time to finally address this annoyance with VSC.

title: Special characters in .env variables not correctly escaped
body:
Essentially the same as issue #50302, seems like you missed escaping a character.
 
- VSCode Version: 1.36.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set up any python project
2. Create a .env file with BUG=HELLO>LOOKAFILE
3. Start debugging 

The ">" character is not correctly escaped and will cause a file that begins with "LOOKAFILE" to be created in the current directory.

While you can cut a collapsed code block and paste it elsewhere, when you paste it, it "uncollapses." 

It would be really cool and useful if the code remained collapsed after you pasted it. 

Thanks.

title: Omit locations visited by incremental search from 'Go back' history
body: Issue Type: Feature Request I often use CTRL + F to repeatedly jump between two or more locations in a file. I could be saved some typing if I could CTRL+F to the second location and then simply "Go back" (ALT + Left Arrow) to the first location. This currently doesn't work with incremental search enabled, because many unrelated locations are visited in the file as each character is typed into the search dialog. Especially the first few characters. **I'd like to see a setting to omit locations visited as a result of incremental search from the 'Go back' history.** VS Code version: Code 1.36.1 (2213894ea0415ee8c85c5eea0d0ff81ecc191529, 2019-07-08T22:59:35.033Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.17763

title: Make it more obvious to accept current or incoming changes for merge conflicts
body:
Compare:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/490562/61944204-3e607a00-aff1-11e9-9cb5-efdc04a15865.png)

vs

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/490562/61944240-56d09480-aff1-11e9-8aa5-7696369f93b0.png)

I find myself looking for the action button to accept one of the two code versions in VS Code a lot. Atom displays this really prominently, with an obvious button which are separated and placed strategically above and below the respective code, and also coloured to match the code.

This makes it so easy to see and hit the right button for what you want to merge.

In VS Code by contrast the buttons are not only tiny so that they are almost invisible, they are on the same line which makes it confusing as you have to remember each time what is the current change and what is the incoming change. 

It'd be great if this bit of UX could get some attention in an upcoming release to make it more obvious what you're doing, and easier to quickly hit the right button.

It would make resolving multiple merge conflicts so much faster.

Thank you.

title: Suppress recommendations for conflicting extensions
body:
**TL:DR**; once the user has installed an extension that conflicts with a recommended one, it'd be helpful to stop recommending it.

Hi! As part of LLVM, I work on the `clangd` C++ language server, which has a [vscode plugin](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=llvm-vs-code-extensions.vscode-clangd).

Microsoft also has the [vscode-cpptools](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-cpptools) language server for C++.

We've noticed that the recommended extension system makes it hard to get clangd set up and keep it working. I'm sure this wasn't the intent - it's a great system for getting new users set up with working tools. However, there's a few interacting issues here here:
 - the `vscode-cpptools` and `clangd` extensions conflict in various ways, and can't be used together
 - the `vscode-cpptools` extension is recommended to anyone opening a c++ file (fair enough)
 - the `vscode-cpptools` extension is called only "C/C++" in the recommendation dialog, which is confusing to users that want C/C++ support from a different language server
 - the `vscode-cpptools` extension continues to be recommended when opening C++ files, even once `vscode-clangd` is installed.

In practice, we've found that a very large fraction of new VSCode users specifically trying to install clangd end up with both extensions installed and active eventually, and we need to include explicit instructions about how to remove this plugin.

So a couple of suggestions, which I don't think will hurt the new-user path or adoption of recommended extensions:
 - Allow extension metadata to include a list of UUIDs for conflicting extensions (like the opposite of `extensionDependencies`). This would suppress recommendation of that extension, and potentially allow VSCode to flag conflicts between installed extensions to the user.
 - Include the publisher name when prompting to install a recommended extension. e.g. `The 'C/C++' extension from Microsoft is recommended for this file type`. This makes the scope clearer to the user I think.

(#77957 will improve this experience a little for users who understand what's going on, but I don't think is sufficient.)

title: Option to Roll Back Last Update
body:
Same as https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/49442, but it's locked...so no-one has a way to bump up its priority.

Users need a way to revert the last update applied.

I applied the most recent update, and restarted the app...now I cannot do my work.  Will have to decide if a tool that breaks on me is really a good choice going forward.

If this isn't fixed soon, I will have no choice but to completely abandon this tool.

title: Window shuts down when remote disconnects while debugging EH
body:
- Debug the remote-ssh extension using the typical extensionHost debug launch config
- Set `"remote.SSH.showLoginTerminal": true` just to make this easier
- Connect to a remote
- Find the "install" terminal and kill it
- The extension development host window closes

This is due to this:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/3b5ee24ca3e3eaf12d730a5ac9dd72f3669aa954/src/vs/workbench/services/extensions/common/remoteExtensionHostClient.ts#L120-L124

I don't know why we need this, it makes sense to test reconnection while developing an extension too.

milestone.title: Backlog

- VSCode Version: 1.31.1 (work-locked to this version)
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch vs code
2. Try to use a keyboard macro.
3. Fail. Very Frustrate. Search Web. Very more Frustrate. nada nada nada.
